verses.text: Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit in the wilderness
verses.comment: Here we see the role of the Holy Spirit guiding Jesus, highlighting the unity of the Trinity. The obedience of Jesus to the Spirit anticipates the Christian life, led by the Spirit towards holiness.

verses.text: for forty days, being tempted by the devil. He ate nothing during those days, and when they were ended, he was hungry.
verses.comment: The forty days recall Israel’s time in the wilderness and Moses' fasting. Jesus succeeds where Israel failed, showing Himself as the new Israel. The literal hunger also shows his true humanity.

verses.text: The devil said to him, 'If you are the Son of God, command this stone to become bread.'
verses.comment: Satan challenges Jesus’ identity and tempts him to use divine power for Himself. This reflects the messianic expectation of a miracle-worker, yet Jesus chooses humility and trust.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'It is written, “Man shall not live by bread alone.”'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Deuteronomy, pointing to the sufficiency of God’s word. The response emphasizes spiritual nourishment, reflecting the tradition of relying on the Word and God’s provision.

verses.text: The devil took him up and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
verses.comment: This dramatic supernatural vision shows the enemy’s attempt to entice Jesus with authority and power. Note the “moment of time” indicating miraculous means.

verses.text: And the devil said to him, 'To you I will give all this authority and their glory, for it has been delivered to me, and I give it to whom I will.'
verses.comment: The devil claims authority over worldly kingdoms, a temporary dominion allowed by God. Jesus’ refusal points to the coming spiritual kingdom which transcends earthly rule.

verses.text: If you, then, will worship me, all will be yours.'
verses.comment: Worship is reserved for God alone; Jesus later teaches this. The temptation is for Jesus to bypass suffering for immediate authority, yet the true path goes through the cross.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'It is written, “You shall worship the Lord your God, and him only shall you serve.”'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Scripture again, prioritizing obedience over power. This shows how the Church’s worship is rightly directed and rejects all idolatry.

verses.text: He took him to Jerusalem, set him on the pinnacle of the temple, and said to him, 'If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from here.'
verses.comment: Now the temptation centers on spectacle, asking Jesus to prove His divine status by miraculous intervention at the heart of Jewish worship—the Temple.

verses.text: For it is written, 'He will command his angels concerning you, to guard you,'
verses.comment: The devil misquotes Scripture, twisting its meaning to tempt Jesus. This highlights the need for proper interpretation of the Word, as found in apostolic tradition.

verses.text: and, 'On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.'
verses.comment: Again, the Scriptures are used as part of the temptation, but Jesus shows discernment, teaching us to rely on wise guidance regarding the Bible’s meaning.

verses.text: And Jesus answered him, 'It is said, “You shall not test the Lord your God.”'
verses.comment: Jesus’s refusal shows the proper trust in God’s timing rather than seeking signs. This affirms a faith that rests in God’s promises, not demands proof.

verses.text: And when the devil had finished all this tempting, he departed from him until a more opportune time.
verses.comment: This hints that temptation will return, especially during the Passion. Christ’s victory here foreshadows His final victory over evil.

verses.text: Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and news about him went out through all the surrounding region.
verses.comment: The Spirit continues to guide Jesus. His public ministry begins in Galilee, fulfilling prophetic hopes for a light to the nations (Isa. 9:1).

verses.text: He taught in their synagogues, being praised by everyone.
verses.comment: The teaching ministry of Jesus begins within the Jewish community. Reception is initially positive, showing how God’s plan unfolds gradually.

verses.text: He came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up. As was his custom, he went to the synagogue on the Sabbath day and stood up to read.
verses.comment: Jesus observes Jewish practices, indicating continued respect for worship gatherings and scriptural readings, which later Church communities inherit in their liturgies.

verses.text: The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him. Unrolling it, he found the place where it was written:
verses.comment: Jesus initiates his ministry with a prophetic reading, indicating intentional fulfillment of messianic prophecy.

verses.text: “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He has sent me to announce release to the captives and recovery of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are oppressed,”
verses.comment: Jesus applies Isaiah’s prophecy to himself, claiming a unique anointing and mission, with both physical and spiritual implications. This affirms his messianic identity and divine sonship.

verses.text: “to proclaim the year of the Lord’s favor.”
verses.comment: This refers to the Jubilee, a time of grace and restoration. Jesus inaugurates a new era of redemption, fulfilling Old Testament hopes in his person and ministry.

verses.text: He rolled up the scroll, gave it back to the attendant, and sat down. The eyes of everyone in the synagogue were fixed on him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ action is deliberate, commanding attention and expectation. This moment sets up his declaration of fulfillment, underscoring his authority as the Messiah.

verses.text: He began to say to them, 'Today this Scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing.'
verses.comment: With these words, Jesus makes an explicit claim to be the prophesied One, a claim of divinity by fulfilling messianic prophecy in himself.

verses.text: All were speaking well of him and marveling at the gracious words coming from his mouth. And they said, 'Isn’t this Joseph’s son?'
verses.comment: There is an initial positive reaction coupled with skepticism. The mystery of Jesus’ person—both divine and human—is introduced by reference to his earthly parentage.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Surely you will quote this proverb to me: “Physician, heal yourself!” What we have heard you did in Capernaum, do here in your hometown as well.'
verses.comment: Here, Jesus anticipates their demand for signs. The 'Physician, heal yourself' saying foreshadows the challenges and rejection he will face, especially at the cross.

verses.text: He said, 'Truly, I say to you, no prophet is accepted in his hometown.'
verses.comment: This principle is seen throughout Scripture where prophets meet rejection among their own people. It foreshadows the broader rejection of Jesus.

verses.text: But I tell you truly, there were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah, when the heavens were shut for three years and six months, and there was a great famine over all the land.
verses.comment: Jesus references Old Testament history, reminding listeners that God’s mercy often worked outside the boundaries of Israel, hinting at the universal scope of salvation.

verses.text: Yet Elijah was sent to none of them, but only to Zarephath, in the region of Sidon, to a widow there.
verses.comment: God’s favor extended to a Gentile widow, illustrating how God's grace transcends ethnic Israel. This prefigures the later inclusion of the Gentiles in Christ's Church.

verses.text: And there were many lepers in Israel at the time of Elisha the prophet, yet none of them was cleansed except Naaman the Syrian.
verses.comment: Again, God’s healing extended to a Gentile. Jesus teaches that grace is not confined to prior boundaries, foreshadowing the mission of the Church to all nations.

verses.text: When they heard these things, everyone in the synagogue was filled with rage.
verses.comment: The message that God’s favor would go to outsiders provokes anger, revealing the challenges inherent in Jesus’ universal mission.

verses.text: They rose up, drove him out of the town, and brought him to the edge of the hill on which their town was built, to throw him down from the cliff.
verses.comment: Jesus’s rejection at Nazareth is an early foreshadowing of his Passion, where the chosen one is spurned by his own.

verses.text: But he passed through their midst and went on his way.
verses.comment: Jesus’s escape here shows divine authority and protection, suggesting that his hour had not yet come—as seen in other Gospel passages.

verses.text: He went down to Capernaum, a city in Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Capernaum becomes a central base of ministry for Jesus. His continuous teaching, especially on the Sabbath, underlines his commitment to ongoing instruction and fulfillment of the Law.

verses.text: They were amazed at his teaching, because his word was spoken with authority.
verses.comment: Jesus’s authority surpasses that of other teachers, signifying his unique status as the Son of God and giver of divine revelation.

verses.text: There was a man in the synagogue who had the spirit of an unclean demon. He screamed out loudly,
verses.comment: Encountering the powers of darkness in a house of worship, Jesus’s ministry begins to manifest a spiritual authority beyond earthly teaching.

verses.text: 'Ha! What do you have to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!'
verses.comment: Even demons recognize Jesus’s divine identity, calling him 'the Holy One of God.' This is a high christological confession, though from an adversary.

verses.text: But Jesus rebuked him, saying, 'Be silent and come out of him!' And after throwing the man down among them, the demon came out of him without causing any harm.
verses.comment: Jesus’s word alone banishes evil, showing absolute authority over spiritual forces. His power demonstrates the reality of liberation brought by his ministry.

verses.text: And all were amazed and said to each other, 'What is this word? For with authority and power he commands the unclean spirits, and they come out!'
verses.comment: Jesus’s command over demons testifies to his unique divine authority. This moment signals the inauguration of the Kingdom of God among men.

verses.text: News about him spread throughout every place in the surrounding region.
verses.comment: The fame of Jesus grows as people witness his power. This sets the stage for the gathering of disciples and the growth of his ministry.

verses.text: He left the synagogue and entered Simon’s house. Now Simon’s mother-in-law was suffering from a high fever, and they asked Jesus to help her.
verses.comment: Simon (Peter) becomes prominent as Jesus responds to his family’s need, foreshadowing Peter’s future leadership among the disciples.

verses.text: He stood over her, rebuked the fever, and it left her, and immediately she got up and began to serve them.
verses.comment: Physical healing and immediate restoration lead to service, showing the role of healing and gratitude in Christian life and ministry.

verses.text: As the sun was setting, everyone who had any who were sick with various diseases brought them to him. He laid his hands on each one and healed them.
verses.comment: Imposition of hands is introduced by Jesus, an act later seen in apostolic ministry for healing and commissioning. The personal touch foreshadows sacramental life.

verses.text: Demons also came out of many, crying, 'You are the Son of God!' But he rebuked them and would not allow them to speak, because they knew he was the Christ.
verses.comment: The demons' recognition of Christ’s divine identity further confirms his status, yet Jesus keeps this revelation veiled until the appropriate time, maintaining the mystery of the Messiah.

verses.text: At daybreak, he went out to a deserted place. The crowds searched for him and came to him, trying to keep him from leaving them.
verses.comment: Jesus’s withdrawal into solitude for prayer displays the importance of communion with God, a pattern continued by early believers.

verses.text: But he said to them, 'I must proclaim the good news of the kingdom of God to the other towns also; for that is why I was sent.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s mission encompasses all people, not just one area, establishing the universal nature and reach of the church as the herald of the kingdom.

verses.text: And he kept preaching in the synagogues of Judea.
verses.comment: Jesus’s ongoing proclamation in synagogues shows consistent engagement with existing religious communities, laying foundations for the apostolic ministry that would continue his work.
